Posts.Content: Mar 31, 2011 01:18PM - edited Mar 31, 2011 01:18PM by mollyart Candice, thank you so much for sharing your positive news. It gives us hope. Like you, I take my sister for treatments and I feel so much better when I'm able to "help" her. Your news made my day.

Posts.Content: Mar 24, 2011 09:07AM mollyart wrote: Dear Stella,  My sister was diagnosed with IV in Dec10. The only way I think I can handle this is if she allows me to DO for her. It makes me feel better to do everything I can for her.  I'm so happy you're allowing your family to show their love. It will be something they'll always remember and feel good about. Keep fighting.

Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2014 11:46PM mollyart wrote: Chrissyb, Thank you so much for your reply. You helped me put all this in context. I wish my sister would get on and talk with all of you. I think she would find great comfort in being with a group that truly understands what she is going through. thanks again for taking the time to help people with questions
Posts.Title: If you are not Stage IV but have questions, you may post here chrissyb Olma61

Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2014 11:52PM mollyart wrote: Can I ask one more thing? My sister was on Afinitor. She told me her blood counts were very low and they will not put her on chemo. They do not know if this was caused by the drug or by the cancer. She has been put on oxycodone.  How long will it take to get her blood count up? Will it recover now that she's off the medicine? Sorry to ask so many questions. I do not want to press her...but I really want to understand.
Posts.Title: If you are not Stage IV but have questions, you may post here chrissyb Olma61

Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2014 02:20AM mollyart wrote: Hello girls. It will be 4 years in November that I first got on here and asked questions for my dear sister. She had 2 1/2 years of NED before the mets came back to bones and a tiny spot on her liver. When she and I are lucky enough to spend time together she does not want to discuss the cancer or her treatments, so I respect that. She wants to have fun. She was suppose to come visit this weekend but just texted me...." at the doctors...blood counts are really low. I'm so tired. Besides that they found cancer on my spine and I have to get an MRI tomorrow night. I might need radiation treatments there". Can you all tell me what this means? Her docs had told her back in June that she should go on chemo, but gave her the option of trying  a combined hormone treatment for the summer. She choose that over chemo. Obviously that didn't work and there's been progression. What happens next? My sister has been a "mother hen" to EVERYONE her entire life. Whenever someone has a problem they call her. She puts everyone ahead of herself. Since her diagnoses 4 years ago she's doubled down on doing things for other people. She has not rested at all...just the opposite. It bums me out that she is SO exhausted from carrying for others...but I know that's the way SHE wanted to spend this time. She is the strong one that everyone leans on.  She has worked so hard to make everyone else feel okay about her situation. I doubt even now she'll put herself first...but I'm hoping. Please tell me what to expect next? Shouldn't she be resting? Having a calm less stressful lifestyle? She just goes and goes and goes....not wanting to disappoint others. I've begged her to slow down...but she dismisses the thought and insists she's fine. Today's text was the first time she admitted how exhausted she is. I'm really worried and want to help.  thank you so much
Posts.Title: If you are not Stage IV but have questions, you may post here chrissyb Olma61

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2011 10:08PM - edited Feb 27, 2011 04:13PM by mollyart You are all so kind to reply. It helps me so much to understand what she's going through and what to expect. I can't wait until she's ready to meet you all. She's hilarious and finds humor in everything, so she'll fit right in.  Kim has raised 4 boys....they are now 27,25,23 and 21. Two weeks after she was diagnosed, Kim found out her oldest and his wife are expecting the first grandchild to our family. So many great things to look forward to. Thank you all for your kind words....it's like I have access to "experts".
Posts.Title: Stage IV girls, can you help me? mollyart Lowrider54

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2011 04:23PM mollyart wrote: Thank you all for your advice. I understand now why there's no chemo. My sister and I laugh in disbelief that we ever wasted a minute worrying about wrinkles, looking older, etc....Now we realize  just how ridiculous and trivial appearance is. This disease sure helps get priorities straight....
Posts.Title: Stage IV girls, can you help me? mollyart Lowrider54

Posts.Content: mollyart wrote: Hello, I am posting for sister. She has had stage IV for 4 years now. She has never acted sick a single day. She has always been vague about the treatments she is receiving. My family, Mom and Dad and brother all thought things were going well based on the way she acted. Over the past 4 years, she never sat down...has been busy and doing everything for others. I spent a few days at the beach with her 10 days ago and all seemed fine. We just got a call that she's been hospitalized at Johns Hopkins to get the pain under control. Her husband now admits she has a "new' tumor" in abdomen, "new" tumor on liver, activity in multiple lymph nodes and a tumor on her lower spine that is pushing on nerves. The blood work shows low white blood counts & platelets. He husband  has asked me to tell my family. Could you all please tell me if there's anything positive I can pass on? Is there any hope for moving on to a new treatment? They are looking into radiation for the spine. She had been on A & A for the past 3 months. I believe now she was told of progression then 3, 6 12 months ago.. 3 months ago refused chemo because she had a wonderful summer planned and went for it. Can she not have chemo now because of the blood count? Does this mean hospice? I need to be strong to help my family cope with this. I need them to understand where we are at. It is just such a shock since she has chosen to deal with this and not tell. We respect that... it's just so hard to have it all hit at once. Thank you for your advice. I've looked on this site and learned so much from you all.  You've gotten me out of many dark moments and given me hope. I just have to be strong for her and my family. I am posting for my dear sister. Dx 12/4/2010, IDC, 2cm, Stage IV, Grade 2, 7/7 nodes, mets, ER+/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Please...could you give me advice? mollyart DivineMrsM

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2014 10:42AM mollyart wrote: Redwolf.....My sister has only had the chemo that comes in pill form. I know she had Tamoxofin, some type of shots, and over the summer Affinitor and Aromasin (sorry about the spelling). She wanted to put off the chemo till after the summer because she had all these fun trips and things to do. She did have a wonderful summer...but she is really tired. Maybe it's because of the low blood counts. I am hoping she'll feel well enough to get on a chemo soon.   thanks again....
Posts.Title: Please...could you give me advice? mollyart DivineMrsM

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2014 01:22PM mollyart wrote: Thanks Maureen. I apologize for posting here. I will take you suggestion.
Posts.Title: Please...could you give me advice? mollyart DivineMrsM

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2014 10:16AM mollyart wrote: I can't tell you how much you've all helped! She has kept us so in the dark that we all felt like we'd gotten a call that said she'd been in a serious accident....We were just all shocked. Everything you've said is coming true. (thank god) They've been able to get her pain under control with 12 hour release and she is scheduled to begin radiation on the spine next week. They are keeping a close eye on her platelets. I believe you all that this is a roller coaster and this is just a low spot. She may be able to come home today. I cannot thank you enough for helping my family. We have not wanted to have her time spent with us talking about cancer. When she's with us she sings, laughs, whistles... she use to dance a lot but the SE make her knees hurt. Anyway...she's always been the cheerleader of the family. She's going to feel bad that the cat is out of the bag. I am working with my family to not make HER make us feel better! My 50 year old brother is taking it very hard....said he thought she'd been cured. We had intentionally kept things from him...he is a recovering alcoholic and very fragile. Thanks again to everyone...coming here is like meeting with a team of specialists all in one place. I wish my sister would come here...maybe now she will.
Posts.Title: Please...could you give me advice? mollyart DivineMrsM

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2014 10:35AM mollyart wrote: Maureen 813....It would be impossible for you to offend me. I was worried that I shouldn't be bothering all of you. Everyone here is so patient and kind and generous with their time and advice. I wanted to ask you all the questions because I can't ask me sister. Thank you all so much for your help.
Posts.Title: Please...could you give me advice? mollyart DivineMrsM

Posts.Content: mollyart wrote: I have been lurking and I just have to reach out and ask your advice. I am posting for my sister who is too scared and shocked to research for herself. Kim is 53 and was diagnosed on Dec 4, 2010 with IIb IDC. In order to be part of a clinical trial, she was given a PET scan. It showed a tiny dot on her right hip that everyone thought was a scar from roller blading. They tried to do two bone biopsies (scrape?) and finally had to do a needle aspiration. Well, some cells came back positve for BC, so now she is a stage IV. She had a double mx on Feb 2 and had 7 nodes removed. All seven came back positive. She had 19 rads on the hip and was told it was "erradicated".  She is getting her drains out and will begin 35 rads on the right breast area (only breast with BC). She has been taking Tamoxifin.  GIRLS, can you tell me why she isn't getting any CHEMO? Is it because she just had the one met and they "cured" it? Wouldn't chemo help? They said something about "saving" chemo. Do you all think that sounds right? I don't want to scare her and have her second guess her doctors. She is being treated at Johns Hopkins. Thanks for any advice. I am posting for my dear sister. Dx 12/4/2010, IDC, 2cm, Stage IV, Grade 2, 7/7 nodes, mets, ER+/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Stage IV girls, can you help me? mollyart Lowrider54

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2011 06:56PM mollyart wrote: Thank you all for your advice. I feel like I already know you, as I have kept up with you over the past month or so. I want to be informed, so that when my sister tells me something I can act like, "oh, well I read about...." instead of acting surprized or scared.  I hope she soon will be able to come on and meet you all. It has helped me so much to meet you  and see how you've dealt with challenges. Here, it is treated more like, oh by the way, I have mets....where as in my world when  I mention IV to any of my friends and they act like....."ohhhhh". You know, like who needs that! Nikola, She was initially IIb based on biopsy. Had had mammo 9 months earlier with ultra sound. Her breast specialist (for the last 15 years) said he thought it was just a shadow (ignored puckering skin!) The doctors at Johns Hopkins seemed shocked that he'd not been more concerned A YEAR AGO..... Post surgery and PET, 7/7 nodes with a bone met... now she's IV. Oh well, can't change the past. She's had dense breasts,cysts biopsies for YEARS. She'd really tried to do everything she could do be pro active. So she's really bummed. I believe the girls here when they write..... "it will get better". It has gotten better already from the initial shock...so I have faith in what they say.
Posts.Title: Stage IV girls, can you help me? mollyart Lowrider54

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2011 07:05PM mollyart wrote: Can I ask one more question? Kim had 3 drains from the double mx. She was able to get the second one removed today, but the last one is still putting out 50ml(?) per day and she has to leave it in. Is having three normal? Does it mean anything to have that many? She had the surgery on Feb 2nd, is it normal to still have one in this long? sorry to sound so uninformed. My sister is coming on Monday for a weeks "vacation" before she starts her rads. I want to sound like I understand. I love her so much it hurts. She is the light in all of our lives and this is hard.
Posts.Title: Stage IV girls, can you help me? mollyart Lowrider54
